chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a suspected sprain or strain?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a person presents with a suspected sprain or strain, with acute joint or muscle pain, and/or swelling, and/or bruising:

  • Ask about:
    • The mechanism and timing of injury.
      • Sudden rapid inversion and internal rotation of the ankle/foot complex may suggest a lateral ankle sprain.
      • Acute hamstring strains typically present suddenly, often after sprinting.
      • Consider the possibility of physical abuse or domestic violence, depending on clinical judgement.
    • The symptoms, including severity and duration.
      • Symptoms of a sprain typically include pain around the affected joint, tenderness, swelling, bruising, pain on weight-bearing, and decreased function.
      • Symptoms of a strain typically include muscle pain, cramping, and spasm; muscle weakness, inflammation, and/or bruising.
      • A 'pop' heard or felt at the time of injury may suggest an anterior cruciate ligament knee injury or hamstring strain.
      • Features of chronic joint instability include persistent pain, swelling, perception of the joint 'giving way' with weight-bearing, recurrent injury, and persistent reduced function (particularly if a sprain is severe or in recurrent injury).
      • Note: the severity of symptoms depends on the severity of the injury as well as time since injury. Symptom duration of more than a few days can suggest more severe injury.
    • The person's usual physical activity level.
    • Any other risk factors for injury or re-injury.
    • Any previous sprain, strain, or joint instability, including treatments and outcome. Use of any current bracing or taping.
  • Examine the person for typical signs and possible complications.
    • Observe for signs of swelling, bruising, limb deformity, or asymmetry/misalignment that may suggest fracture or dislocation.
      • Note: it can take up to 24 hours for the full extent of bruising to become apparent.
      • Note: examination of an acutely injured or painful joint can be difficult owing to pain, swelling, and guarding.
    • Palpate the joint or muscle, including for point tenderness and joint line tenderness.
      • Replication of the person’s ‘known pain’ on palpation and/or stressing of a ligament may indicate ligament injury.
    • Assess the range of joint movement, strength testing, signs of joint instability, coordination and balance, ability to weight-bear, and gait. Perform additional specific joint tests, such as the anterior drawer test of the ankle, if clinically appropriate.
      • In ankle injuries with bruising and pain on palpation around the distal fibula, and/or a positive anterior drawer test, a rupture of the lateral ankle ligaments is likely.
      • In hamstring injuries, examination of the hip and lumbar spine should also be performed to identify any other potential causes of posterior thigh pain.
    • Perform a neurovascular examination to assess for peripheral nerve injury and check peripheral pulses are intact and symmetrical.
  • Consider arranging referral to an Emergency Department for an X-ray, depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • Needed to assess the extent of an injury and/or for associated injuries.
    • A fracture or other complication is suspected. See the section on X-ray clinical decision rules for more information.
    • An alternative diagnosis is suspected.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: X-ray clinical decision rules
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Consider use of a clinical decision rule to assess whether X-ray imaging is needed.

  • The Ottawa rules recommend an X-ray in the following cases:
    • Following an ankle injury, if there is pain in the malleolar zone, and one of the following:
      • Inability to bear weight (walk four steps) immediately after the injury and when examined.
      • Bone tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the fibula or tip of the lateral malleolus.
      • Bone tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the tibia or tip of the medial malleolus.
    • Following a foot injury, if there is pain in the midfoot zone, and one of the following:
      • Inability to bear weight (walk four steps) immediately after the injury and when examined.
      • Bone tenderness at the base of the fifth metatarsal.
      • Bone tenderness of the navicular bone.
    • Following a knee injury, if there is one or more of the following:
      • Inability to bear weight (walk four steps) at the time of injury and when examined.
      • The person is aged 55 years or more.
      • Tenderness at the head of the fibula.
      • Isolated tenderness of the patella.
      • Inability to flex the knee to 90 degrees.
  • An X-ray is also recommended:
    • Following a wrist injury, if there is:
      • Pain or tenderness over the scaphoid bone (palpate at the base of the anatomical snuff box and scaphoid tubercle).
  • Note: the Ottawa rules may be less applicable in certain clinical situations where clinical judgement should be used, for example in people who:
    • Are younger than 18 years of age.
    • Are confused, have a cognitive deficit, communication problems, or are intoxicated, as the person's expression or perception of pain can be altered.
    • Have polytrauma, head injury, or diminished sensation in the lower extremities (for example due to neurological deficit).
    • Have gross swelling making palpation of the area impossible.
    • Are pregnant.

[Stiell, 1995a; Stiell, 1995b; Stiell, 1996; Perry, 2006; Robb, 2007; Seah, 2011; Jonckheer, 2015; Logerstedt, 2017; Strudwick, 2017; Strudwick 2017; Delahunt, 2018; Strudwick, 2018; Vuurberg, 2018; Chen, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment are largely based on the Dutch publication Clinical practice guidelines for physical therapy in patients with acute ankle sprain [de Bie, 2006], the International Ankle Consortium publications Consensus statement on the prevalence, impact and long-term consequences of lateral ankle sprains [Gribble, 2016], and Clinical assessment of acute lateral ankle sprain injuries (ROAST): 2019 consensus statement and recommendations [Delahunt, 2018], a Dutch consensus statement on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], US clinical practice guidelines Knee stability and movement coordination impairments: knee ligament sprain [Logerstedt, 2017], a systematic review of the evidence for assessing fracture risk following ankle sprains [Jonckheer, 2015], a systematic review of the management of ankle sprains [Seah, 2011], a systematic review of prognostic factors following lateral ankle sprain injury [Thompson, 2017], a systematic review of the Ottowa ankle rules [Bachmann, 2003], a primary care study of predictors of persistent symptoms after ankle sprain [Mailuhu, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles on ankle and foot injuries [Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019; Nickless, 2019], on knee injuries [Robb, 2007; Strudwick, 2017], on hamstring injuries [Chu, 2016], and on clinical decision rules for assessing traumatic injuries [Perry, 2006].

Clinical features on history taking

  • The recommendation to ask about the mechanism of injury is largely based on International Ankle Consortium consensus statements [Gribble, 2016; Delahunt, 2018], clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], and is extrapolated from expert opinion in review articles [Robb, 2007; Chu, 2016; Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019; Nickless, 2019].
    • The information about inversion injuries of the ankle is based on International Ankle Consortium consensus statements [Gribble, 2016; Delahunt, 2018] and expert opinion in a review article [Chen, 2019].
    • The information about hamstring injuries is based on expert opinion in a review article [Chu, 2016].
    • The recommendation to consider the possibility of physical abuse is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be safe clinical practice. It is also supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation to ask about symptoms is based on International Ankle Consortium consensus statements [Gribble, 2016; Delahunt, 2018], a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], the US clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], a primary care study [Mailuhu, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Chu, 2016; Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019].
    • The information on typical symptoms of a sprain is extrapolated from US clinical practice guidelines [Logerstedt, 2017], a primary care study of persistent ankle sprain symptoms [Mailuhu, 2018], and expert opinion in a review article [Chen, 2019]. In addition, the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement notes that levels of self-reported pain and degree of swelling can help to assess the efficacy of treatments [Delahunt, 2018].
    • The information on typical symptoms of a strain is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article [Chu, 2016].
    • The information on the possible clinical significance of a 'pop' at the time of injury is based on US clinical practice guidelines [Logerstedt, 2017] and expert opinion in a review article [Chu, 2016].
    • The information on the features of chronic joint instability is based on International Ankle Consortium consensus statements [Gribble, 2016; Delahunt, 2018], a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], and a primary care study of persistent ankle sprain symptoms [Mailuhu, 2018].
  • The recommendation to ask about the person's baseline functioning is based on the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018], US clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article on ankle and foot injuries [Strudwick 2017].
    • This can help guide exercise-based treatments and assess whether the person has returned to their usual pre-injury functioning [Delahunt, 2018].
    • The US clinical practice guidelines recommend assessing activity level before and after treatment interventions [Logerstedt, 2017].
    • Knowledge about previous functional status and pre-morbid mobility levels can help to guide appropriate education and mobility aids [Strudwick 2017].
  • The recommendation to ask about risk and prognostic factors is based on a systematic review of prognostic factors [Thompson, 2017] and a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018].
    • Factors such as pain level, workload, and level of sports participation may all negatively influence recovery and increase the risk of future re-injury. Modifiable risk factors such as deficits in proprioception and range of movement should be identified and managed, where possible, to reduce the risk for recurrent sprains [Vuurberg, 2018].
    • A systematic review of nine studies found the identification of early prognostic factors associated with poor recovery following lateral ankle sprain injury may provide an opportunity for early-targeted intervention and improve outcomes [Thompson, 2017].
  • The recommendation to ask about previous sprains, strains, or instability, and/or current treatment is based on the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018] and expert opinion in a review article [Chen, 2019].
    • Previous lateral ankle sprain is a primary risk factor for recurrent injury, and may indicate there are unresolved mechanical and/or sensorimotor impairments [Delahunt, 2018].
    • Expert opinion in a review article advises to assess the current use of mechanical supports such as bracing or taping [Chen, 2019].

Clinical features on examination

  • The recommendations on assessment using observation and palpation of the joint or muscle complex, and testing of movement, strength, coordination, and gait are based on the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018], the US clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Chu, 2016; Strudwick 2017; Strudwick, 2017; Chen, 2019; Nickless, 2019].
    • The information that joint deformity or asymmetry may suggest fracture or dislocation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Chen, 2019].
      • Expert opinion in a review article notes that clinical examination of an acutely injured or painful knee joint can be difficult in the emergency setting due to pain, effusion, and guarding. Joint effusion may provide false information on laxity or pain with movement [Strudwick, 2017].
    • Specific points of joint or bony tenderness may help guide the decision to arrange X-ray imaging [Chen, 2019].
      • The information on the possible significance of replication of the person’s ‘known pain’ on palpation and/or stressing of an affected ligament is extrapolated from the consensus statement on ankle sprain injuries [Delahunt, 2018].
    • Assessment for joint laxity is important in ankle injuries to determine the severity of injury and identify any involvement of the syndesmosis (ankle ligament complex), as this may alter management and follow up, and improve identification of alternative conditions such as acute Achilles tendon rupture [Strudwick 2017].
    • An inability to weight-bear after an ankle injury points to a more severe diagnosis, such as an ankle fracture or syndesmotic injury, as opposed to a simple lateral ankle sprain. Such findings influence the decision to arrange X-ray imaging of the joint [Delahunt, 2018; Chen, 2019; Nickless, 2019]. In addition, an abnormal gait may increase the risk of re-injury following acute lateral ankle sprain injury [Delahunt, 2018].
    • The information that additional specific ligament integrity tests may be needed is extrapolated from the consensus statement on ankle sprain injuries [Delahunt, 2018], the US clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article [Strudwick, 2017].
      • The information on the possible significance of a positive anterior drawer test in ankle injuries is based on a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018].
      • The information that additional examination of the hip and lumbar spine should be performed in hamstring injuries to identify any other potential causes of posterior thigh pain is based on expert opinion in a review article [Chu, 2016].
    • The recommendation to perform a neurovascular examination is based on the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Chu, 2016; Chen, 2019].
      • A modified Delhi consensus highlighted the importance of identifying mechanical and/or sensorimotor impairments following lateral ankle sprain injury that are associated with the development of chronic ankle instability [Delahunt, 2018].
      • Residual deficits in proprioception, muscular imbalance, and impaired neuromuscular control that are not identified and managed at the time of initial injury may contribute to the development of chronic ankle instability after ankle sprain [Chen, 2019].

Considering referral for an X-ray

  • The recommendation to consider an X-ray to assess the extent of an injury and/or for associated injuries is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. It is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendations on when to consider arranging an X-ray are based on the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018], US clinical practice guidelines on knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017], a consensus statement on ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], a systematic review of the Ottowa ankle rules [Bachmann, 2003], a systematic review of the evidence for assessing fracture risk following ankle sprains [Jonckheer, 2015], a systematic review of the management of ankle sprains [Seah, 2011], and expert opinion in review articles [Perry, 2006; Robb, 2007; Chen, 2019].
    • The International Ankle Consortium consensus statement recommends use of the Ottowa rules to establish the likelihood of ankle fracture [Delahunt, 2018].
    • A consensus statement on ankle sprains notes that the Ottowa ankle rules are an accurate and valid tool that can be used for people who have a suspected ankle/foot fracture within 1 week after the initial trauma. It states that as only 15% of people with lateral ankle sprain who have an ankle X-ray are diagnosed with an ankle fracture, this decision tool has been developed to rule out the likelihood of fracture [Vuurberg, 2018].
    • An overview of one systematic review and 21 primary studies assessing the most accurate method to assess fracture risk after an acute ankle sprain in adults concluded the Ottawa ankle rules are of utmost importance in identifying people who need an X-ray [Jonckheer, 2015].
      • Sensitivity and specificity of the Ottowa ankle rules range from 92–100% and from 16–51%, respectively.
      • No evidence was found in favour of the use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) in the acute phase of ankle sprain.
      • A limitation of this review was the heterogeneity between the studies that prevented the performance of a meta-analysis.
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes the Ottawa ankle rules are highly sensitive tools for detecting fracture in the setting of acute ankle sprain, and these should be used to reduce unnecessary X-rays after ankle sprain [Chen, 2019]. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article on clinical decision rules [Perry, 2006].
    • The US clinical practice guidelines note the Ottawa knee rule has been developed and validated to determine when X-ray is needed in people with acute knee injury [Logerstedt, 2017]. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Robb, 2007].
  • The information that some comorbid conditions such as cognitive impairment, pregnancy, or excessive swelling may affect the applicability of the Ottowa ankle rules is based on a multicentre study [Stiell, 1995a], and is also extrapolated from a systematic review of the evidence for assessing fracture risk following ankle sprains [Jonckheer, 2015].
  • The recommendation to consider an X-ray if an alternative diagnosis is suspected is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. It is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
